text_1: Coronaviruses are a group of viruses that can affect humans and animals. In humans, coronaviruses can cause mild illness, such as the common cold and gastrointestinal infections, as well as more severe illness, such as that caused by SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) and MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome).

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

text_1: There is currently an outbreak of a disease called ‘COVID-19’, which is caused by a new strain of coronavirus. COVID-19 causes a spectrum of illness, from mild to very severe. The outbreak was first identified in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, and has spread to many other countries. The virus can be spread from person to person, so good hygiene is very important in slowing the spread of infection.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

generalCovidInfo.name: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

text_1: The key symptoms of COVID-19 are:
ulist_1: fever
cough
shortness of breath
sore throat
text_2: Current estimates of the time it takes for symptoms to develop after being exposed to the virus that causes COVID-19 range from 2-14 days.
In more severe cases, COVID-19 can also result in pneumonia. Current estimates of the time it takes for symptoms to develop after being exposed to the virus that causes COVID-19 range from 2-14 days.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

text_1: People can catch COVID-19 from others who have the virus. The disease can spread from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales. These droplets land on objects and surfaces around the person. Other people then catch COVID-19 by touching these objects or surfaces, then touching their eyes, nose or mouth. People can also catch COVID-19 if they breathe in droplets from a person with COVID-19 who coughs out or exhales droplets.

citation.name: Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

generalCovidInfo.name: Is there a cure or vaccine?

text_1: There are currently no vaccines or specific treatment that protect against COVID-19.
Early diagnosis and general supportive care are important. Most of the time, symptoms will resolve on their own. People who have serious disease with complications can be cared for in hospital.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

generalCovidInfo.name: Who is most at risk of getting COVID-19?

text_1: In Australia, the people most at risk of getting the virus are those who have:
ulist_1: Recently been in in a high risk country or region (mainland China, Iran, Italy or Korea)
Been in close contact with someone who has a confirmed case of COVID-19

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

generalCovidInfo.name: Who is most at risk of getting a serious infection?

text_1: Based on what we know about coronaviruses, those most at risk of serious infection are:
ulist_1: People with compromised immune systems (such as people who have cancer)
Elderly people
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples (as they have higher rates of chronic illness)
People with chronic medical conditions
People in group residential settings
People in detention facilities
text_2: It is important for all individuals to practice good hygiene and carry out social distancing to reduce the likelihood of the disease spreading to the more vulnerable parts of the population.

citation.name: Protect yourself and others - Australian Government Department of Health

generalCovidInfo.name: Should I be Bulk-Buying to prepare?

text_1: There is no need to bulk-buy products at supermarkets including toilet paper, paracetamol and canned food.
It is prudent for households to have a small stock of non-perishable groceries to cover the event that in the coming months the household has been asked to self-isolate for 14 days.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

generalCovidInfo.name: What else should I not be doing?

text_1: The following measures are not effective against COVID-19:
ulist_1: Smoking
Wearing multiple masks
Taking antibiotics
text_2: More information about coronavirus myths can be found in the site below.

citation.name: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) advice for the public: Myth busters - World Health Organization

text_1: If you have recently travelled overseas or had contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19, you should closely monitor yourself for symptoms for 14 days of leaving an overseas country or after your last contact with someone who has COVID-19.
If you are within that 14 day period and concerned that you may have symptoms, it’s important that you take steps to reduce the risk of transmission and arrange to get tested if required.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

haveCovid.name: How do I seek medical attention for COVID-19?

text_1: If you have recently travelled overseas or had contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19, you should closely monitor yourself for symptoms for 14 days of leaving an overseas country or after your last contact with someone who has COVID-19.

If you are within that 14 day period and concerned that you may have symptoms, it’s important that you take steps to reduce the risk of transmission and arrange to get tested if required. Take the following steps:
ulist_1: Limit your exposure to other people by isolating yourself at home (if you were not already in home quarantine).

Call your GP and let them know you’re worried you may have COVID-19. Calling ahead will allow your GP to provide advice and plan for your visit. You should not visit your GP without calling ahead. Testing will be arranged by your GP if they determine it is necessary.
If you can’t see your GP, you can visit a Respiratory Assessment Clinic. Staff at these clinics will assess your risk of COVID-19 and test you if needed. You do not need to call ahead.

When travelling to the GP or Respiratory Assessment Clinic, do not attend any public places, such as shops or cafes/restaurants, on the way. If possible, you should travel using a private mode of transport, such as a private car, to minimise exposure to others.

However, if using public transport is your only option, you should wear a mask, avoid direct contact with other people (including other passengers, drivers and transport staff), cough/sneeze into your elbow, and wash your hands before and after you travel.
You do not need to visit the Emergency Department unless you have severe symptoms, such as shortness of breath, chest pain or very high fever.

citation.name: Protect yourself and others - Australian Government Department of Health

haveCovid.name: Should I be tested for COVID-19?

text_1: Your doctor will tell you if you should be tested, and they will arrange for the test
You will only be tested if your doctor decides you meet the criteria:
ulist_1: You have returned from overseas or spent time on a cruise ship in the past 14 days and you develop respiratory illness with or without fever
You have been in close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case in the past 14 days and you develop respiratory illness with or without fever
You have severe community-acquired pneumonia and there is no clear cause (including patients that have already been hospitalised for this condition)

You have a fever or acute respiratory infection and you work in the healthcare or aged/residential care sectors, or you have spent time in a location that's defined by a state or territory as having an elevated risk of community transmission, or you have spent time at a "high-risk" location where there are two or more linked cases of COVID-19, such as an aged-care home, a remote Aboriginal community, a correctional facility, a boarding school, or a military base (including Navy ships) with live-in accommodation.
text_2: If you meet any of these criteria, your doctor can request you are tested for COVID-19. It is important to remember that many people with symptoms similar to COVID-19 will not have the virus. Only suspected cases are tested to ensure our labs are able to cope with the demand. There is no need to test people who feel well and do not meet the criteria above.
There is a global shortage of testing kits, so that is why testing is targeted rather than widespread.

It may take a few days for you to get your test results. In this time, if you have serious symptoms, you will be kept in the hospital and isolated from other patients to keep them safe. If your doctor says you are well enough to go home, you should self-isolate at home and take measures to protect yourself and others.
The Government has also decided to allow states and territories to expand their testting criteria as required. Please ensure you check your state's health department's resources.

citation.name: How to get a coronavirus test: who is eligible, how many have been done and how are they carried out - ABC News
COVID-19 - Frequently Asked Questions - NSW Ministry of Health
Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

haveCovid.name: What does isolate in your home mean?

text_1: If you have been diagnosed with COVID-19, you must stay at home to prevent it spreading to other people. You might also be asked to stay at home if you may have been exposed to the virus.
Staying at home means you:
ulist_1: Do not go to public places such as work, school, shopping centres, childcare or university
Ask someone to get food and other necessities for you and leave them at your front door
Do not let visitors in — only people who usually live with you should be in your home
text_2: You do not need to wear a mask in your home. If you need to go out to seek medical attention, wear a surgical mask (if you have one) to protect others.
All people who arrive in Australia from midnight 15 March 2020, or think they may have been in close contact with a confirmed case of coronavirus, are required to self-isolate for 14 days.
Refer to the sources below for more information.

citation.name: Home isolation guidance when unwell (suspected or confirmed cases) - Australian Government Department of Health
Isolation guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

text_1: All people who arrive in Australia from midnight 15 March 2020, or think they may have been in close contact with a confirmed case of coronavirus, are required to self-isolate for 14 days.

Under the current lockdown, the government is also asking people who are not confirmed or suspected COVID-19 cases not to leave their homes unless they need to for groceries, exercise, medical needs, care or support or work which cannot be from home.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently asked questions - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: How can I protect myself and others?

text_1: The best way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is the same way you would protect yourself from catching flu or other respiratory illness:
ulist_1: Clean your hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and water, or use an alcohol-based sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol. [Refer to the image at the top of the page]
Cover your sneeze or cough with your elbow or with tissue.
Dispose of tissues properly
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth.
Clean and disinfect surfaces and frequently used objects such as phones, wallets, and keys regularly
Avoid close contact with people who are ill.
Stay home if you are sick.
Avoid non-essential travel
Wear a surgical mask if you are coughing or sneezing. Note there is little evidence to suggest that widespread use of surgical masks in healthy people prevents transmission in public.
Get your flu shot when it’s available. Getting the flu and COVID-19 at the same time can make you very ill.
Practice social distancing
Abide by all government lockdown regulations and recommendations

citation.name: Protect yourself and others - Australian Government Department of Health

text_1: Social distancing is one way to help slow the spread of viruses such as COVID-19. Social distancing includes staying at home when you are unwell, avoiding large public gatherings if they’re not essential, keeping a distance of 1.5 metres between you and other people whenever possible and minimising physical contact such as shaking hands, especially with people at higher risk of developing serious symptoms, such as older people and people with existing health conditions.

citation.name: COVID-19 - Frequently asked questions - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: What is the theory behind social distancing?

text_1: The current scientific consensus is that this virus can be spread within 2 meters (6 feet) if somebody coughs. Otherwise, the droplets fall to the ground and don’t infect you.

The worst infection then becomes through surfaces: The virus survives for up to 9 days on different surfaces such as metal, ceramics and plastics. That means things like doorknobs, tables, or elevator buttons can be terrible infection vectors.
The only way to truly reduce that is with social distancing: Keeping people home as much as possible, for as long as possible until this recedes.

citation.name: Coronavirus: Why You Must Act Now - Tomas Pueyo

protect.name: What does it mean when people say, ‘flatten the curve’ and ‘raise the line’ and how does social distancing help?

video_1.desc: Beating Coronavirus, Flatten the Curve, Raise the Line

text_1: “Flattening the curve,” refers to reducing the spread of the virus to ensure that the health system is not overloaded. “Raising the line,” refers to increasing the capacity of the health system. It is imperative that everyone do their part to flatten the curve and raise the line through social distancing and practicing good hygiene, to reduce the impact of the pandemic.
Additional information about “flattening the curve,” and “raising the line,” can be found in the resources below.

citation.name: Coronavirus: The Hammer and the Dance - Tomas Pueyo
Coronavirus: Why You Must Act Now - Tomas Pueyo

protect.name: How do I practice social distancing in public?

text_1: Social distancing in public means people:
ulist_1: Stay at home unless is absolutely necessary
Keep 1.5 metres away from others
Avoid physical greetings such as handshaking, hugs and kisses
Use tap and pay instead of cash
Travel at quiet times and avoid crowds
Avoid public gatherings and at risk groups
Practise good hygiene

citation.name: Social distancing guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: How do I practice social distancing at home?

text_1: To reduce the spread of germs:
ulist_1: Stay at home unless going out is absolutely necessary
Keep visitors to a minimum
Reduce visits to the shops — instead, buy more goods and services online if you can for pick-up, pre-order or delivery
Carefully consider what travel and outings are necessary, both individual and family
Regularly disinfect surfaces that are touched a lot, such as tables, kitchen benches and doorknobs
Increase ventilation in the home by opening windows or adjust air conditioning

citation.name: Social distancing guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: What if people in my household are ill?

text_1: Households where people are ill (ie have an undiagnosed respiratory illness or fever), in addition to the measures above, should:
ulist_1: Care for the sick person in a single room if possible
Keep the number of carers to a minimum
Keep the door to the sick person’s room closed and, if possible, a window open
Wear a surgical mask when you are in the same room as the sick person. The sick person should also wear a mask

Protect other vulnerable family members by keeping them away from the sick person. At-risk people include those over 65 years or people with a chronic illness. If possible, find them somewhere else to live while the family member is sick.

citation.name: Social distancing guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: How do I practice social distancing at work?

text_1: To reduce the spread of germs in the workplace:
ulist_1: Stay at home unless is absolutely necessary
Stop handshaking as a greeting
Hold meetings via video conferencing or phone call
Defer large meetings
Hold essential meetings outside in the open air if possible
Promote good hand and sneeze/cough hygiene and provide hand sanitisers for all staff and workers
Eat lunch at your desk or outside rather than in the lunch room
Regularly clean and disinfect surfaces that many people touch
Open windows or adjust air conditioning for more ventilation
Limit food handling and sharing of food in the workplace
Avoid non-essential travel
Promote strict hygiene among food preparation (canteen) staff and their close contacts
Consider if you can reschedule, stagger or cancel non-essential meetings

citation.name: Social distancing guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: How can my children practice social distancing in school?

text_1: To reduce the spread of germs in the schools:
ulist_1: Wash hands with soap and water or use hand sanitiser when entering school and at regular intervals
Stop activities that lead to mixing between classes and years
Avoid queuing
Cancel school assemblies
Have a regular handwashing schedule
Regularly clean and disinfect surfaces that many people touch
Conduct lessons outdoors where possible
Consider opening windows and adjusting conditioning for more ventilation
Promote strictest hygiene among food preparation (canteen) staff and their close contacts
text_2: If your child is sick, they must not go to school or childcare. You must keep them at home and away from others.

citation.name: Social distancing guidance - Australian Government Department of Health

protect.name: What else can I do to help reduce the spread?

text_1: To help reduce the spread of coronavirus, WHO also recommends:
ulist_1: Wash your hands frequently using soap and water or alcohol-based hand rub
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth
Cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or a tissue when you cough or sneeze
Stay at home if you feel sick
If you have a fever, cough or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention early – be sure to call in advance and follow the directions of your local health authority
Stay informed and follow advice given by your healthcare provider

citation.name: Q&A on coronaviruses (COVID-19) - World Health Organization

regulations.name: What are the current government limits on indoor and outdoor gatherings?

text_1: As of March 30th, both indoor and outdoor gatherings have been limited to two persons only. Exceptions to this limit include:
ulist_1: People of the same household going out together
Weddings are restricted to no more than five people, including the couple, the celebrant and the witnesses. The 4 square metre rule and social distancing must be observed.
Funerals must be limited to no more than 10 people. The 4 square metre rule and social distancing must be observed.
Family units
text_middle: It is recommended that you stay home except for:
olist_1: Shopping for what you need - food and necessary supplies
Medical or health care needs, including compassionate requirements
Exercise in compliance with the public gathering requirements
Work and study if you can’t work or learn remotely

citation.name: Limits on public gatherings for coronavirus (COVID-19) - Australia Government Department of Health

regulations.name: What are the current government limits on public facilities and businesses?

text_1: The following facilities have been restricted from opening as of 30th of March:
ulist_1: Pubs, registered and licensed clubs (excluding bottle shops attached to these venues), hotels (excluding accommodation)
Gyms and indoor sporting venues
Cinemas, entertainment venues, casinos and night clubs
Restaurants and cafes will be restricted to takeaway and/or home delivery
Religious gatherings, places of worship or funerals (in enclosed spaces and other than very small groups and where the 1 person per 4 square metre rule applies)
Food courts (except for take away)
Auction houses, real estate auctions and open houses
Personal services (beauty, nail, tanning, waxing and tattoo salons)
Spa and massage parlours, excluding health related services such as physiotherapy
Amusement parks, arcades and play centres (indoor and outdoor)
Strip clubs, brothels and sex on premises venues.
Galleries, national institutions, historic sites and museums
Health clubs, fitness centres, yoga, barre and spin facilities, saunas, bathhouses and wellness centres and swimming pools
Community facilities such as community halls, libraries and youth centres, RSL and PCYC
Gaming and gambling venues
Indoor and outdoor markets (excluding food markets). States and territories will make their own announcements about this.
Playgrounds, skate parks and outside gyms in public places will be closed
Bootcamps will be reduced to two persons, including the trainer.
text_2: These measures also apply to the outdoor areas associated with each of these venues. Australians should expect these measures to be in place for at least 6 months. Isolated remote community hubs are not included in these restrictions.

Public transport is considered essential and, at this stage, the 100 person limit does not apply. If traveling on public transport, always use appropriate social distancing and hygiene practices, and avoid non-essential travel.
There are special regulations are in place for visiting aged-care facilities. More information can be found in the sources below.

citation.name: National Cabinet Statement
Fact Sheet: For families and residents on restricted visits to residential aged care facilities - Australian Government
Limits on public gatherings for coronavirus (COVID-19) - Australia Government Department of Health

text_1: All people entering Australia must self-isolate for 14 days. You may board a domestic flight to your intended destination in Australia to self-isolate there. You can travel to Australia if you are an Australian citizen, a permanent resident, an immediate family member of an Australian citizen or permanent resident or are a New Zealand citizen usually resident in Australia. If you are an immediate family member holding a temporary visa you will need to provide evidence of your relationship.
